confession.seduction_context: Approached her when she was in despair after her child drowned, asking reason for her sadness. Offered her a purse if she would serve him, but he and the purse disappeared after touching her forehead upon acceptance. This occurred before her husband's death 14 years earlier.

devil_mark.description: Insensible mark found on her head by executioner; she claimed it came from a blow given by children guarding animals at Fresnel

sabbat_activities: 7 or 8 people present, men in white cloth or dressed normally

witnesses.name: Didier Drouat
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: debtor relationship through son-in-law Pierot Cugnin

testimony.quarrel_subject: Money owed by Pierot Cugnin (son-in-law of accused); had to resort to force to obtain payment

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: 2 years earlier - leg became shorter than the other, but was cured 3 days after encounter with her
came home from fields to find wife in bed with limbs affected, 12 days after money dispute

witnesses.name: Anne Marchal, veuve Mre Jean Chasquin, femme Jean Merlin
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: victim's widow; her first husband was surgeon who obliged accused's son-in-law

testimony.quarrel_subject: First husband (surgeon) obliged her son-in-law Pierot Cuinin to give caution for his debts
testimony.threat_quote: she told him he would repent

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: Immediately after returning home, whole body became swollen, ill for 9 months until death
12 years earlier, promptly fell ill and died after refusing to give 'ung bat de chausse'

witnesses.name: Demenge Cuinin le Bourdier et cordonnier

testimony.quarrel_subject: Asked father to sell her wood, but he refused saying he had none to sell

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: Went into stable, 3 hours later cow died

testimony.quarrel_subject: Had forbidden her to visit his house due to reputation
testimony.threat_quote: she had said he had no reason to fear her, and she would do him no harm

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: 7 or 8 years earlier accused came into house, child became ill, dying 4 years later
Same story as husband - thought she would die but recovered after being helped by curé of Vomécourt
Same story as daughter about death of cow

testimony.quarrel_subject: Had sometimes forbidden her his house
testimony.threat_quote: she said she would do him no harm

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: Had once given him 5 apples (type called Paradis) which were marked and full of holes - suspected some evil, and threw them away

witnesses.name: Joseph serviteur a Philippe du Hault

testimony.quarrel_subject: 2 years before was guarding pigs when she came towards him; she told him she would do him no harm, and said she was on her way to steal wood from the priest while he was in church
testimony.threat_quote: told him she would do him no harm

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: 9 or 10 years earlier son had lost use of both legs; father asked Margueritte to come and visit. She went into kitchen with milk pot in hand and broom under arm; put broom down, then took it away with her again, after which child recovered

testimony.quarrel_subject: More than 2 years earlier she came to house asking wife to sell her wood; after several refusals went to door of stable, turned round, and came back. Repeated this 3 times, then asked to buy milk, which was also refused

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: After refusals only cow sickened; after 3 days was advised to threaten her. He did so, saying he would beat her. She replied 'Ma foy Demenge je n'y veulx aller', and within hours cow recovered

testimony.quarrel_subject: 2 years earlier she had been seeking alms in village, and was refused by his wife Claude
testimony.threat_quote: When wife told her she had been very ill since refusal, accused replied 'qu'elle vouloit doncques dire qu'elle luy avoit donné le mal'

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: Shortly afterwards fell ill with mouth twisted. Died 3 months later, suspecting she had bewitched her

witnesses.name: Mainne femme Didier Mongenot, de Bralleville

testimony.quarrel_subject: 18 months before she came to door begging to be let in because son of Grand Humbert was coming after her to beat her. Witness refused because she suspected she was a witch, but husband told her to let her in. She took dried pears from cupboard

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: After eating dried pears that accused had touched, developed swelling still causing great pain. Afflicted with 5 or 6 beasts the size of rats that appeared at all hours, sometimes mounting to head, arms, hands; when she wanted to eat or drink the beasts mounted to throat to take the food. The beasts changed into several forms of animals, like crows, little pigs, etc.

witnesses.name: Humbert Journel le jeune, de Hergugney

testimony.quarrel_subject: Had previously come asking for wife, then had her take splinter from foot

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: 18 months before his wife died after 6 day illness, during which she threw herself about so they could hardly hold her. Kept saying that Margueritte had given it to her, and these were last words

witnesses.name: Claudon femme Gerard Tisselot, de Hergugney

testimony.quarrel_subject: 3 years before was washing at spring when Margueritte approached, saying she had not eaten and was very thirsty. Witness was afraid of her, went off to hang washing on hedge, then went home

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: Then became very ill for 2 months. Visited priest at Charmes who told her she was bewitched and to look in the bed where she slept. Found hare's feet, pieces of sheet, and other things

timeline.subject: PG des Vosges
timeline.details: PG des Vosges has received advice that Margueritte, vulgarly called la Geline, was much feared as witch by those in villages around, where she had been begging for 20 years or more. Asks prévôt at Mirecourt to take depositions.

timeline.subject: Margueritte Liegey
timeline.details: PG des Vosges gives order for arrest; further depositions taken from witnesses 5-9

timeline.subject: Margueritte Liegey
timeline.details: Depositions from witnesses 16-17; PG des Vosges asks for arrest and interrogation

timeline.subject: Margueritte Liegey
timeline.details: Said she was widow of Bartremin Liegey, marguilier of Ambacourt, aged about 60. Denied she was a witch, admitted she had been accustomed to beg around villages.

timeline.subject: Margueritte Liegey
timeline.details: Admitted some occasions when she had been accused of causing deaths or illnesses. Noted that she showed no emotion, merely replied promptly to questions.

timeline.subject: Margueritte Liegey
timeline.details: Confrontations with witnesses including Claudon femme Didier Drouot, Joseph, Claude du Hault, Jean Vuillemin dit Saulnier, and Jean Friant

timeline.subject: Margueritte Liegey
timeline.details: PG des Vosges asks for question ordinaire et extraordinaire

timeline.subject: Margueritte Liegey
timeline.details: Interrogation under torture. Began to waver before torture, but only confessed when thumbscrews were applied to hands and feet. Said she had been seduced by Persy some 6 years earlier. Retracted, then given tortillons. Confessed she had been to sabbat more than 7 times and was a witch.

timeline.subject: Margueritte Liegey
timeline.details: Said it had been 18-20 years since she became a witch, before death of husband 14 years earlier, when they had a child who drowned. Confessed to making several people ill and killing others. Renewed confessions that afternoon.

timeline.subject: Margueritte Liegey
timeline.details: Confirmed she was witch; said there had been 7 or 8 people at sabbat but did not know them

timeline.subject: Margueritte Liegey
timeline.details: PG des Vosges asks for death sentence, but that she be tortured again first to ask her about accomplices

timeline.subject: Margueritte Liegey
timeline.details: Change de Nancy asks that before deciding on further action she be asked whether she actually renounced God, and how

timeline.subject: Margueritte Liegey
timeline.details: Interrogation under torture. Said others at sabbat were men in white cloth. Admitted she had renounced God at first meeting. Finally given thumbscrews, persisted she knew no accomplices. PG reiterates request for death sentence.

notable_quotes.speaker: Claudon Mathieu
notable_quotes.french: Sorciere que luy voudrois tu faire il en a assez du sien
notable_quotes.english: Witch, what would you do to him, he has enough of his own
notable_quotes.context: Said to Margueritte when she asked to come to Didier Drouat's poisle

notable_quotes.speaker: Margueritte Liegey
notable_quotes.french: pauvre homme vous avez bien de mal, dieu ne vous veult il pas faire aller droict
notable_quotes.english: poor man you have much pain, does God not want to make you walk straight
notable_quotes.context: Said to Didier Drouat when she found him by a hedge, repeated several times; he was cured within 3 days

notable_quotes.speaker: Didier Drouat
notable_quotes.french: et ne peult croire aultrement qu'elle ne soit ensorcellée
notable_quotes.english: and cannot believe otherwise than that she is bewitched

notable_quotes.speaker: Anne Marchal
notable_quotes.english: she told him he would repent
notable_quotes.context: Threat given to her first husband Jean Chasquin after he obliged her son-in-law to give caution for debts

notable_quotes.speaker: Joseph
notable_quotes.french: ne scauroit asssé souhaiter la mort de Margueritte Poirson
notable_quotes.english: cannot wish enough for the death of Margueritte Poirson
notable_quotes.context: After becoming ill following encounter with accused

notable_quotes.speaker: Margueritte Liegey
notable_quotes.french: Ma foy Demenge je n'y veulx aller
notable_quotes.english: My faith Demenge I do not want to go there
notable_quotes.context: Response to Demenge Saulnier's threat to beat her; within hours his cow recovered

notable_quotes.speaker: Margueritte Liegey (to Jean George's wife)
notable_quotes.french: qu'elle vouloit doncques dire qu'elle luy avoit donné le mal
notable_quotes.english: that she wanted therefore to say that she had given her the illness
notable_quotes.context: Response when wife told her she had been very ill since refusing alms

notable_quotes.speaker: Priest at Charmes
notable_quotes.french: que pour vray elle estoit ensorcelée et qu'en signe de ce qu'on regarde deans les licts la ou ladite deposante couchoit et l'on y trouveroit merveilles
notable_quotes.english: that truly she was bewitched and as a sign of this look in the bed where the deponent slept and one would find marvels
notable_quotes.context: Told to Claudon femme Gerard Tisselot; she found hare's feet, pieces of sheet, and other things

notable_quotes.speaker: Margueritte Liegey
notable_quotes.french: lors qu'ilz heurent un enffant noyé qui causa son desespoir, il y peut avoir quelques 18 a 20 ans qu'elle est telle
notable_quotes.english: when they had a child who drowned which caused her despair, it may have been some 18 to 20 years that she has been such
notable_quotes.context: Confession under interrogation about when she became a witch

notable_quotes.speaker: Mainne femme Didier Mongenot
notable_quotes.french: des bestes jusques a cinq ou six y en ayant d'icelles de la grosseur d'un rat, qui paroissent a toutte heure, tantost elles montent jusques au sommet de la teste tantost aux bras et mains et autres membres, et quand elle veult manger ou boire les bestes montent jusques a la gorge pour prendre les viandes, lesdites bestes se changeantes en plusieurs formes d'animaux, comme de corbeaux, de petits pourceaux et aultrement
notable_quotes.english: beasts up to five or six, some the size of a rat, which appear at all hours, sometimes they mount to the top of the head sometimes to the arms and hands and other members, and when she wants to eat or drink the beasts mount to the throat to take the food, the said beasts changing into several forms of animals, like crows, little pigs and otherwise
notable_quotes.context: Description of her affliction after eating dried pears touched by Margueritte

relationships.evidence_text: widow (from last marriage) of Bartremin Liegey, marguilier of Ambacourt
Didier Drouat and his wife Claudon femme Didier Drouot
Joseph serviteur a Philippe du Hault
his niece Manne (who is Marie femme Didier Mengenot)

economic_context.details: Margueritte was a beggar who had been begging for 20 years or more. Multiple disputes arose from refusals to give her alms, sell her wood or milk. Her son-in-law Pierot Cugnin owed money to Didier Drouat and had to be forced to pay. Anne Marchal's first husband (a surgeon) obliged Pierot Cuinin to give caution for his debts, leading to her threat.

harms_catalog.harm_description: leg became shorter than the other; later completely cured after encounter with accused
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: 2 years before testimony; cured 3 days after encounter
harms_catalog.method_alleged: words/proximity - she said 'poor man you have much pain, does God not want to make you walk straight'

harms_catalog.harm_description: first one limb then another affected

harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Didier Drouat had to resort to force to obtain payment from Pierot Cugnin (son-in-law of accused)

harms_catalog.harm_description: whole body became swollen, ill for 9 months until death; doctors and apothecaries could not identify disease
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: obliged her son-in-law Pierot Cuinin to give caution for his debts; she told him he would repent

harms_catalog.harm_description: fell ill and died, saying to the end that accused had given her the illness

asked father to sell her wood but he said he had none to sell

harms_catalog.method_alleged: went into kitchen with milk pot in hand and broom under arm; put broom down, then took it away with her again, after which child recovered

material_culture.context: Margueritte repeatedly asked to buy or was accused of stealing wood
Asked to buy milk; offered milk to sick member of family; left by fire with milk and dried pears
Anne Marchal's sister refused to give her 'ung bat de chausse'
Claude du Hault said she had given him 5 apples which were marked and full of holes
Left by fire with dried pears; took some from cupboard; Mainne ate them and became ill
Went into kitchen with pot in hand and broom under arm; put broom down, then took it away
Went into kitchen with pot in hand containing milk
Boiled cow's heart to test for witchcraft; she appeared first at house asking for fraissure
Found in bed of bewitched woman as sign of witchcraft
Found in bed of bewitched woman as sign of witchcraft
Persy (devil) offered her a purse if she would serve him, but it disappeared

Village where Jean George lived; where his wife was killed
Where incident with woman refusing to lodge Margueritte occurred; where Humbert Journel pursued her
Where Humbert Journel le jeune and Claudon femme Gerard Tisselot lived; where Grand Humbert lived
Where curé helped Claudon femme Didier Drouot recover
Where priest told Claudon femme Gerard Tisselot she was bewitched
Where she was going when crying about drowned child; where she renounced God at first meeting with devil
Where she claimed children guarding animals gave her a blow on the head
Joseph claimed he started to feel spell after passing Poussay
Where Joseph was waiting for confrontation and felt spell worsen
Location of Change de Nancy court that approved torture and reviewed case
Where Claudon femme Gerard Tisselot was washing when Margueritte approached
Where she met Jean Friant and said there would be a storm; where Jean Friant claimed she tried to drown him

weather_events: storm mentioned in woods with Jean Friant
economic_hardship_indicators: Margueritte was a beggar for 20 years or more
debt disputes involving her son-in-law Pierot Cugnin/Cuinin
theft of wood mentioned multiple times
people refusing to sell wood or milk to beggar

hearsay_chains.content: repeated claims that Margueritte had bewitched him
that she had killed his wife
story about how she had given illness to a woman at Bralleville who had refused to take another into her house
she had killed his wife who had refused her alms
she had tried to drown him in the woods

hearsay_chains.source: his cousin Marie, femme Didier Mengenot of Bralleville
hearsay_chains.content: she had given her illness after she had not wanted husband to lodge her in their house
Margueritte had caused illness by witchcraft

emotional_state_notes: showed no emotion during interrogation of 18 July 1624
retracted confession saying she had only said what she had to be released
confused and in pain during torture
asked that they put her to death

third_parties.name: Claudon Mathieu
third_parties.relationship_to_witness: present when accused spoke to Didier Drouat
third_parties.context: Said to accused 'Witch, what would you do to him, he has enough of his own'

third_parties.name: Pierot Cugnin/Cuinin
third_parties.context: Owed money, had debts that caused disputes; told witnesses of reputation; claimed he had told wife and mother-in-law to harm no one but had not been able to be master

third_parties.name: Lucye
third_parties.context: Didier Drouat believed his wife was bewitched by Margueritte or her daughter Lucye

third_parties.name: Jean Chasquin
third_parties.relationship_to_witness: first husband of witness 2; mentioned by witness 3
third_parties.context: Surgeon who obliged Pierot Cuinin to give caution for debts; died after 9 months of swelling illness

third_parties.name: sister of Anne Marchal
third_parties.context: Refused to give accused 'ung bat de chausse', fell ill and died 12 years earlier

third_parties.name: Jean George of Bujieux/Puzieux
third_parties.relationship_to_witness: mentioned by witness 3; testified as witness 16
third_parties.context: Claimed she had killed his wife who refused her alms

third_parties.name: Grand Humbert of Hergugney
third_parties.context: Son chased Margueritte to beat her; told story about illness given to woman at Bralleville

third_parties.name: Jean Friant le viel
third_parties.context: Said she had tried to drown him in the woods; beat her some days after storm incident

third_parties.name: Phillebert Renault
third_parties.context: Son lost use of both legs; asked Margueritte to come and visit; child recovered after her visit

third_parties.name: Marie/Manne, femme Didier Mengenot of Bralleville
third_parties.relationship_to_witness: cousin of witness 11; niece of witness 15; testified as witness 17
third_parties.context: Suffered illness after not wanting husband to lodge Margueritte in their house

third_parties.name: Claude (wife of Jean George)
third_parties.context: Refused alms, fell ill with mouth twisted, died 3 months later

third_parties.name: wife of Humbert Journel
third_parties.context: Died after 6 day violent illness, kept saying Margueritte had given it to her as last words

third_parties.name: Bartremin/Barthelemin Liegey
third_parties.context: Marguilier of Ambacourt; died 14 years before trial

third_parties.name: drowned child of Margueritte
third_parties.context: Drowned 18-20 years before trial, causing her despair which led to seduction by devil

third_parties.name: Persy (devil/master)
third_parties.context: Approached her when crying about drowned child; offered purse if she would serve him; touched her forehead; gave her powder at first sabbat meeting

third_parties.name: son of Grand Humbert of Hergugney
third_parties.context: Chased Margueritte to beat her because believed she had made his wife ill

third_parties.name: Demenge George of Puzieux
third_parties.context: Wife refused her alms several times according to accused's testimony

third_parties.name: Margueritte Poirson
third_parties.context: Joseph said 'cannot wish enough for the death of Margueritte Poirson' - possibly alternate surname or confusion

extraction_metadata.notes: Complete trial record with 19 witnesses, detailed confessions under torture, timeline from July 10 to August 7, 1624. Trial ended with death sentence being requested. Margueritte was a widow and beggar who had been feared as a witch for 20+ years. Notable features: extensive catalog of harms including human deaths, animal deaths, and unusual afflictions (e.g., shape-shifting beasts); confession obtained under torture about seduction by devil named Persy following child's drowning; powder given at sabbat; refused to name accomplices despite repeated torture. Some name variations (Cugnin/Cuinin, Bujieux/Puysieux/Puzieux, Mongenot/Mengenot, Margueritte Poirson) noted. Rich economic context of begging, debt disputes, and refusals of charity.
